title: Scalars and vectors-claim based on cart velocity

content.question: Time <math alttext="(in seconds)" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi mathvariant="normal">s</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></math> Position <math alttext="(in meters)" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mpadded><mo>(</mo><mpadded><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></mpadded><mo>)</mo></mpadded></math> Velocity <math alttext="(in meters per second)" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mtext>m</mtext><mo>/</mo><mtext>s</mtext><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></math> <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> <math alttext="1.00" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1.00</mn></math> <math alttext="negative 0.2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mpadded><mo>-</mo><mn>0.2</mn></mpadded></math> <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> <math alttext="0.80" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>0.80</mn></math> <math alttext="negative 0.2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mpadded><mo>-</mo><mn>0.2</mn></mpadded></math> <math alttext="3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>3</mn></math> <math alttext="0.75" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>0.75</mn></math> <math alttext="0.1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mo> </mo><mn>0.1</mn></math> <math alttext="4" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>4</mn></math> <math alttext="1.00" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1.00</mn></math> <math alttext="0.4" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mo> </mo><mn>0.4</mn></math> <math alttext="5" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>5</mn></math> <math alttext="1.40" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1.40</mn></math> <math alttext="0.4" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mo> </mo><mn>0.4</mn></math> The table shows the position and velocity of a cart on a straight track at several moments in time. Which of the following claims about the motion of the cart is supported by the data in the table?

choices.label: The cart only moved in the positive direction because the position of the cart was always positive.
The cart only moved in the positive direction because the velocity was never zero, so the cart did not stop and change direction.
The cart moved first in the positive direction and then in the negative direction because it was moving faster at the end of the recorded motion.
The cart moved first in the negative direction and then in the positive direction because the velocity of the cart was negative and then changed to positive.

content.answer: The cart moved first in the negative direction and then in the positive direction because the velocity of the cart was negative and then changed to positive.

topic.text: 1.1: Scalars and Vectors in One Dimension

skill.text: 3.C: Justify or support a claim using evidence from experimental data, physical representations, or physical principles or laws.
